questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune Suite.
You use Microsoft Intune to manage devices.
Azure AD joined Windows devices enroll automatically in Intune.
You have the devices shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You are preparing to upgrade the devices to Windows11. All the devices are compatible with Windows 11.
You need to evaluate Windows Autopilot and in-place upgrade as deployment methods to implement Windows 11 Pro on the devices, while retaining all user settings and applications.
Which devices can be upgraded by using each method? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
//IMG//

discussion.content:
someone explain me how to upgrade From Windows 11 from autopilot?
In the first option I think None of the devices
In the second 1 & 3 (2 it´s 32 beats)

Bit of a vague question. The question states: while retaining all user settings and applications.

Windows autopilot is possible on all devices (upload hash) but it will wipe all data. So is the answer then 'non of the devices'?

The inplace update is only possible on device 1 and 3 because there doesnt exist a 32bit version of W11

Correct me if im wrong

comments.content: It says all devices is compatible with Win 11 but there is a 32 bit machine..
Win10 OS can be 32-bit or 64-bit version, even device is 64-bit. Win11 offer only 64-bit version and always need 64-bit device.

With windows autopilot we cannot update Windows versions.
To update to Windows 11 we would need to configure the updates but that section is no longer within autopilot. Your question would be well posed, if instead of Autopilot, in the question, put Intune.
(at least I think so)

discussion.content: But if the question says "All the devices are compatible with Windows 11." we shouldn't be bothered about device 2 being 32-bit

1. None of the Devices
2. Device 1 and 3 only

autopilot: none, only dev1 can, but only with wipe because autopilot, so: no
in place: 32 bit need a wipe, so dev1 no. dev1 and dev3 yes

Answer is correct because you have the sentence "Azure AD joined Windows devices enroll automatically in Intune." so Device1 is the only registered in intune and then it will get the autopilot deployment Profile. As there is no Windows 11 32 bit version in place upgrade is not possible for Device 2

If I read the question correctly it states that all the devices are compatible with Windows 11. Which could be true if you reinstall the OS software with 64-bit (as long as the hardware can install 64-bit which it states saying they are compatible with Windows 11). Even though installing a in-place upgrade on a 32-bit wouldn't work because windows 11 doesn't accept 32-bit workstation, so a re-installation should be needed to do that. So yeah Device 1, and Device 2 are able to do a in-place upgrade.

There is no Windows 11 32-bit so upgrade to 32Bit OS is not possible. Upgrade to 64-bit would need a wipe which won't work with the question. 
Also you can upload the device hash but to truly make them autopilot devices, they'll need a wipe. 
Hence: 
None
Device 1 and 3

- None (Autopilot doesn't upgrade windows versions, it leverage existing OEM installed)
- Device1 and Device3 only due the 32 bit of device 2

Windows Autopilot: None of the devices. [User settings and app will not be retained using any Autopilot scenarios]

In-place Upgrade: Device 1 & 3 only [Device 2 is 32-bit and not eligible]

comments.content: it took me a few times to re-read the part on AutoPilot, but I go for this answer.

discussion.content:
The answer is correct as is. 

The questions asks how to upgrade. Autopilot will only run on a device that is enrolled in Autopilot (i.e. - the hardware hash has been uploaded.) All devices enrolled in Autopilot have an Entra Joined entry. 

Without knowing anything else, my assumption is that Device 1 will run autopilot and upgrade to Windows 11. There is no line of business app preventing it. Users settings will hopefully be saved in cloud. (That is my only concern with this question). Otherwise the other two devices are not entra joined so we cannot assume they are enrolled in autopilot. The second part of the question will in place upgrade both and retain user info for sure, 32 bit not supported as already discussed.

comments.content: Also Device 2 is 32 bit.

discussion.content: Only device 1 can be upgrade by using Autopilot as only this device is automatically enrolled in Intune. Autopilot require MDM service such as Intune. Device 2 and 3 are not enrolled in Intune so they can not be upgrade by Autopilot.

- None
- Device1 and Device3 only

according to this link you can update via Autopilot, but only after you login and Feature updates are installed - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/windows-10-feature-updates#limitations-for-feature-updates-for-windows-10-and-later-policy

Windows Autopilot is a powerful tool for deploying and managing Windows devices in an efficient and streamlined manner. However, it’s essential to clarify that Windows Autopilot primarily focuses on device provisioning, which includes tasks like device registration, configuration, and deployment. Here are some key points related to your question:
Device Deployment and Configuration:
Windows Autopilot simplifies the initial setup of Windows devices by automating tasks such as domain join, app installation, and policy enforcement.
It doesn’t directly handle Windows upgrades (upgrading from Windows 10 to Windows 11) as its primary purpose is to get devices ready for use.
The answer is correct due to the line of business app, I overlooked that.
The only possible answer here is 1 and 3 only on both

Autopilot: None of the devices > Autopilot doesn't upgrade OS, and doesn't retain user data.

"You need to evaluate Windows Autopilot and in-place upgrade as deployment methods to implement Windows 11 Pro on the devices, while retaining all user settings and applications."

Auto pilot doesn't update the device OS version
in place upgrade always possible if upgrade path available, can't do that for 32bit to 64bit so device 1 and device 3

Windows Autopilot for existing devices lets you reimage and provision a Windows device for Autopilot user-driven mode using a single, native Configuration Manager task sequence. The existing device can be on-premises domain-joined. The end result is a Windows 10 or Windows 11 device joined to either Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) or Active Directory (hybrid Azure AD join).

comments.content:
You seem to be right as I can only find references that upgrade from Windows 10 to 11 through WUfB, with that being said:

"Feature updates for Windows 10 and later policies cannot be applied during the Autopilot out of box experience (OOBE). Instead, the policies apply at the first Windows Update scan after a device has finished provisioning, which is typically a day"

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/windows-10-feature-updates#limitations-for-feature-updates-for-windows-10-and-later-policy

discussion.content:
"none of the devices" - You cant upgrade windows version through autopilot, you have to use Intune Features Updates

Device 1 and 3 only - In-place Upgrade for 32 bits to 64 is not supported. 

Tricky one

1 - Autopilot requires no existence in AzureAD (Think of OEM devices enrolled), hashID-s needs to be uploaded and that is it. (Works with VMs as well), so all device can work.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/autopilot/software-requirements#next-steps
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/autopilot/networking-requirements
2 - 32-bit has no in-place upgrade option as W11 comes only with 64bit version

comments.content:
yes but with Hybrid, the devices have to be already joined however it is irrelevant here:

User-driven mode for Microsoft Entra hybrid join
Windows Autopilot requires that devices be Microsoft Entra joined. If you have an on-premises Active Directory environment, you can join devices to your on-premises domain. To join the devices, configure Autopilot devices to be hybrid-joined to Microsoft Entra ID.
But device 2 has Win10 32 bit installed, in that case an in place upgrade to Win11 64 bit isn’t possible right? Regardless whether the hardware supports it?

Correct. 

It would need to be a 32-bit in-place upgrade. But Win11 is only available in 64-bit, so a full wipe and install is needed.
actually they are not new computers lol

How can devices be Azure AD "joined" in advance for new computers ? I can understand they have to be uploaded into Intune (unique identifier) before staging, if they are Computers already AD joined, existing devices, well they are already known and in Intune, I think Feature Updates would be used and not Autopilot
No devices qualify for Autopilot, Autopilot requires having WIndows 11 already

discussion.content:
1 - Autopilot requires being in AzureAD, other two devices are not joined.
But "All devices are compatible with Windows 11", then all support 64 bit OS. Then:
1, 2 & 3 can be updated.

1 - Autopilot requires being in AzureAD, other two devices are not joined.
1 & 3 - CPU requirement is 64bit for windows 11 - https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/windows-11-specifications#table1 -

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have 100 computers that run Windows 10.
You plan to deploy Windows 11 to the computers by performing a wipe and load installation.
You need to recommend a method to retain the user settings and the user data.
Which three actions should you recommend be performed in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
//IMG//

discussion.content: This is yet another annoying one, yes the answers are theoretically correct but in ANY workplace known to man, you ALWAYS take a backup / snapshot of a device with user data on. Does Microsoft not actually deal with anything like this themselves for such vague questions?

answers are correct
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/usmt/usmt-scanstate-syntax
MDT is not even supposed to be on the exam anymore so I don't know how relevant these questions are. But given answers are correct, however weird they may be.

To retain user settings and user data while performing a wipe and load installation of Windows 11 on 100 computers, you should follow these steps in sequence:

Run scanstate.exe. This will capture the user state from the existing Windows 10 installations.
Deploy Windows 11. This will perform the wipe and load installation of the new operating system.
Run loadstate.exe. This will restore the user state to the new Windows 11 installations.
Provided answer is correct.

Answer is correct

Run scanstate.exe
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/usmt/usmt-scanstate-syntax

Deploy Windows 11

Run loadstate.ex
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/usmt/usmt-loadstate-syntax
Sounds about right!
considering known folder redirection to onedrive was already configured, this is correct
Correct

Letters is right, but the point here is not the use of KFM, as the combination of it with ESR will do the job the question is stating Wipe and Load installation, meaning the use of USM tool, and the answer is correct.
Reason it isnt KFM for data is that it only backs up specific folders and not all users Appdata folder etc.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune Suite.
You use Microsoft Intune to manage devices.
You use Windows Autopilot to deploy Windows 11 to devices.
A support engineer reports that when a deployment fails, they cannot collect deployment logs from failed device.
You need to ensure that when a deployment fails, the deployment logs can be collected.
What should you configure?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
"Turn on log collection and diagnostics page for end users" set to YES in ESP settings.

ChatGPT
To ensure that deployment logs can be collected when a Windows Autopilot deployment fails, you should configure the enrollment status page (ESP) profile.

The enrollment status page (ESP) in Windows Autopilot allows you to track the progress of the device provisioning process and can be configured to collect logs if the deployment fails.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

C. the enrollment status page (ESP) profile
Answer is correct.

Selected Answer: C
Answer is correct

To deploy the ESP to devices, you have to create an ESP profile in Microsoft Intune. Within the profile, you can configure the ESP settings that control:

Visibility of installation progress indicators.
Device access during provisioning.
Time limits.
Allowed troubleshooting operations.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/enrollment/windows-enrollment-status

Selected Answer: C
C

ESP allows users to collect troubleshooting logs
Correct

Turn on log collection and diagnostics page for end users
Yes, the answer is correct.

comments.content: the premise is there's a support engineer. So manually collecting the log in ESP is the way to do it

According to ChatGPT, setting up ESP is beneficial before deploying through Autopilot.
However, specifically for the purpose of collecting deployment logs when deployment fails, the critical aspects configuring the diagnostic settings within the Autopilot deployment profile. The ESP enhances the deployment process but might not directly influence the collection of logs during a failed deployment.
Configuring the diagnostic settings within the deployment profile is more directly linked to the collection of logs in case of a failed deployment.

discussion.content:
This is what I got from Chat GPT:

To enable the collection of deployment logs when a Windows Autopilot deployment fails, you'll want to adjust settings withing Microsoft Intune: 

1. Enable Diagnostic Settings in Intune: 
Go to Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center
Navigate to Devices>Windows.Windows enrollment> Deployment profiles. 
Choose the specific Autopilot deployment profile used for the deployments.
Within the profile settings, ensure that "Collect diagnostic logs" or similar options are enabled.

Selected Answer: C
Also, here "Allow users to collect troubleshooting logs".
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/autopilot/enrollment-status#esp-profiles

Selected Answer: C
the question is wrong.
because You have logs without any action
but If You would like give end user logs yes You have to setup ESP
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/enrollment/windows-enrollment-status
\

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that contains a user named User1 and uses Microsoft Intune Suite.
You use Microsoft Intune to manage devices.
You have a device named Devic1 that is enrolled in Intune.
You need to ensure that User1 can use Remote Help from the Intune admin center for Device1.
Which three actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
From my point of view, the solution is:
A,B,F

comments.content:
Microsoft 365 E5 subscription include Intune Plan 1, so add-on is required.

https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/business/microsoft-intune-pricing#:~:text=Microsoft%20Intune%20Remote%20Help
I'm not sure what Rerun device onboarding means, but if it is assigning a profile to the Device1 then 3rd answer could be E. Any thoughts?
There is difference in device name, in the first place it is called Devic1 and 2nd time it is called Device1. Should we consider it a typo or another device?

The question states Intune Suite is used, so the license for Remote Help add-on not required, so F is not correct. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/intune-add-ons#available-add-ons

reference:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/remote-help#prerequisites
The license is already assigned in the statement of the question.
Disregard my previous comment. The license assigned is the O365, not the Intune Remote Help!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABF
1. Deploy the Remote Help app to Device1 (A)
The Remote Help app must be installed on the device for remote assistance to work.
You can deploy the app using Intune or manually install it.
2. Assign the Remote Help add-on license to User1 (F)
Remote Help requires a specific add-on license in addition to the Microsoft 365 E5 license.
This license must be assigned to the user who will provide assistance (User1).
3. Assign the Help Desk Operator role to User1 (B)
To use Remote Help from the Intune admin center, User1 must have permissions to initiate remote sessions.
The Help Desk Operator role provides the required Remote Help permissions in Intune.

Selected Answer: ABF
i will go with ABF

A. Deploy the Remote Help app to Device1
B. Assign the Help Desk Operator role to User1
F. Assign the Remote Help add-on license to User1

Selected Answer: ABF
This is the only correct answer

Selected Answer: ABF
1. The Remote Help add-on license is needed for both the user and admin. 
2. The Remote Help app needs to be installed on the device. 
3. The admin or user taking access needs appropriate role before doing so. MS goes by principle of least priviledge so we go for F.

Selected Answer: ABF
To ensure that User1 can use Remote Help from the Intune admin center for Device1, you should perform the following actions:

Deploy the Remote Help app to Device1. The Remote Help app needs to be installed on the device to enable remote assistance.
Assign the Help Desk Operator role to User1. This role provides the necessary permissions to perform remote assistance operations.
Assign the Remote Help add-on license to User1. The Remote Help add-on license is required for using the Remote Help feature.
Therefore, the three actions you should perform are:

A. Deploy the Remote Help app to Device1.
B. Assign the Help Desk Operator role to User1.
F. Assign the Remote Help add-on license to User1.

To ensure that User1 can use Remote Help from the Intune admin center for Device1, you should perform the following actions:

Deploy the Remote Help app to Device1. The Remote Help app needs to be installed on the device to enable remote assistance.
Assign the Help Desk Operator role to User1. This role provides the necessary permissions to perform remote assistance operations.
Assign the Remote Help add-on license to User1. The Remote Help add-on license is required for using the Remote Help feature.
Therefore, the three actions you should perform are:

A. Deploy the Remote Help app to Device1.
B. Assign the Help Desk Operator role to User1.
F. Assign the Remote Help add-on license to User1.

Selected Answer: ABF
CORRECT ANSWER

Selected Answer: ABE
the correct actions are:
- **B. Assign the Help Desk Operator role to User1.**
- **E. Rerun device onboarding on Device1.**
- (Additional information: **A. Deploy the Remote Help app to Device1** is not explicitly required for User1 to use Remote Help, but it's a good practice to have the app installed on the device.) 

Please note that assigning the Intune Administrator role or a Microsoft 365 E5 license is not directly related to enabling Remote Help specifically for User1 and Device1.

comments.content: E5 includes the Remote help license. You don't need an additional license for remote help. A,B,E is correct.
The Remote Help add-on license is essential to unlock the feature for the user, even if they already have a Microsoft 365 E5 license. So no.

discussion.content:
Correct answer is ABF:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/role-based-access-control-reference#help-desk-operator
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/remote-help-windows

Selected Answer: ABF
ABF

F because adding an Intune Remote Help add on is required as part of the pre-req (Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/remote-help#prerequisites)

comments.content: Ref: https://www.prajwaldesai.com/intune-remote-help/

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/remote-help#:~:text=Enable%20Remote%20Help%20for%20your%20tenant%3A%20By%20default%2C%20Intune%20tenants%20aren%27t%20enabled%20for%20Remote%20Help.%20If%20you%20choose%20to%20turn%20on%20Remote%20Help%2C%20its%20use%20is%20enabled%20tenant%2Dwide.%20Remote%20Help%20must%20be%20enabled%20before%20users%20can%20be%20authenticated%20through%20your%20tenant%20when%20using%20Remote%20Help.

A and B and F is correct

Selected Answer: ABF
ABF - looks good for me

In case this helps anyone
https://ctsdemos.azureedge.net/microsoft/Intune/remotehelp/RemoteHelpDemo.html

Selected Answer: ABD
I think A,B,D. A and B are correct, nothing to say. The D answer better fit in the scenario because we don't need Administrator role, there is no need to rerun device onboarding and the add-on license is no needed cause we use intune suite

comments.content:
Great guide! But we don't need the add-on license because the Intune Suite unifies all the features, as Remote Help.
Also in the guide says "To use Intune Remote Help, both the helper and the sharer must sign in with an Azure AD account", so we need to assign E5 license to User1

discussion.content: AB and F is correct, here you have the full deployment https://www.prajwaldesai.com/intune-remote-help/

Selected Answer: ABF
comment no longer too short

Selected Answer: ABD
I am leaning towards A, B, D. 
The question reads: You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that contains a user named User1 and uses Microsoft Intune Suite.
I guess it is understood that User1 already has assigned or will be assigned the Microsoft 365 E5 license.

Selected Answer: ABF
Agree with rmac

Selected Answer: ABF
Vote for ABF
Agree With rmac .. A,B,F

Selected Answer: ABF
agree with RMAC
E5 is not necessary as remote help license can be assigned as addon to other licenses, E5 is 'over-licensing' the user/device.

Selected Answer: ABF
Agree with RMAC, no need to re-onboard the device to MDM when it's already enrolled.

choices.F: Assign the Remote Help add-on license to User1.
choices.D: Assign a Microsoft 365 E5 license to User1.
choices.A: Deploy the Remote Help app to Device1.
choices.C: Assign the Intune Administrator role to User1.
choices.B: Assign the Help Desk Operator role to User1.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-10-deployment-scenarios 
Existing applications are preserved through the process. So, the upgrade process uses the standard Windows installation media image (Install.wim). Custom images aren't needed and can't be used because the upgrade process is unable to deal with conflicts between apps in the old and new operating system.

Selected Answer: B
From: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-deployment-scenarios#in-place-upgrade

Existing applications are preserved through the process. The upgrade process uses the standard Windows installation media image (Install.wim). "Custom images not only aren't needed, but they also can't be used. Custom images can't be used because the upgrade process is unable to deal with conflicts between apps in the old and new operating system." For example, Contoso Timecard 1.0 in Windows 10 and Contoso Timecard 3.0 in the Windows 11 image.

Selected Answer: B
it is clear that custom images cannot be used for an in-place upgrade because the upgrade process cannot handle conflicts between apps in the old and new operating systems.

Therefore, only the default Windows 11 image created by Microsoft (Image2) can be used for the in-place upgrade of Device1.

The correct answer is:

B. Image2 only
You can perform in-place upgrade, only with de default Windows image. Anything else is not supported.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
Custom images not only aren't needed, but they also can't be used. 

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-deployment-scenarios#:~:text=Existing%20applications%20are,Windows%2011%20image.

Selected Answer: B
Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-10-deployment-scenarios#in-place-upgrade
B is correct
Totaly agree with you. Tried it in my Lab

questions.question_text:
You have a Windows 11 capable device named Device1 that runs the 64-bit version of Windows 10 Enterprise and has Microsoft Office 2019 installed.
You have the Windows 11 Enterprise images shown in the following table.
//IMG//

Which images can be used to perform an in-place upgrade of Device1?
